description.plain:
Born on January 16, 1979 in Brooklyn, New York and raised in Detroit, Michigan, Aaliyah Dana Haughton, sometimes referred to as the “Princess of R&B,” was an American singer and actress who debuted in the early ‘90s. In 1989, at age ten, she appeared on the American talent television show, Star Search. In 1994, she made her debut in the music industry with her debut album, Age Ain’t Nothing But a Number.

In 1996, she signed to Atlantic Records and released her sophomore album, One in a Million, which featured music production from Timbaland and songwriting from Missy Elliott. The album had singles, “One in a Million,” “If Your Girl Only Knew,” “4 Page Letter,” and more. Though her music career was evolving, Aaliyah continued her education, being homeschooled by her mother and eventually graduating from the Detroit Performing Arts High School in 1997, with a 4.0 GPA. That same year, “Journey to the Past” was released as part of the 1997 film, Anastasia’s soundtrack. The song later received a nomination for “Music (Original Song)” at the 70th Academy Awards in 1998. “Are You That Somebody?” was released a year later, in 1998, for the film, Doctor Dolittle. By the end of the ‘90s, she had established her career, receiving RIAA Gold certifications for singles “Back & Forth,” “At Your Best (You Are Love),” and “One in a Million.”

After releasing two successful albums, Aaliyah made her debut as an actress in the year 2000. She starred as the role of Trish O'Day alongside actor Jet Li in the Warner Bros film, Romeo Must Die. The film’s soundtrack featured songs by Destiny’s Child, Ginuwine, Playa, Timbaland & Magoo, and the hit single, “Try Again,” which peaked at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 chart for thirty-one weeks, based just on radio play. In July 2001, Aaliyah released her long-awaited self-titled album, Aaliyah. The album featured singles, “We Need A Resolution,” “Rock the Boat,” and “More Than A Woman.”

On August 25, 2001, Aaliyah was tragically killed in a plane crash in The Bahamas. She had just finished filming the music video for her then soon-to-be single, “Rock the Boat.” She won a number of posthumous awards, including winning two awards at the American Music Awards. Before her tragic death, she was casted for the role of “Zee” in films, The Matrix Reloaded and The Matrix Revolutions, but she did not get to finish her scenes, so her role had to be recasted. Her sophomore and final film, Queen of the Damned, was later released posthumously on February 22, 2002.

After a long absence of Aaliyah’s music catalog not being able to stream on streaming platforms, her music finally become available in the months of August-October 2021.

songs.full_title: Are You That Somebody? by Aaliyah
songs.title: Are You That Somebody?

description.plain:
The unusual, stuttering beat of this 1998 single recorded for the Dr. Dolittle soundtrack received great acclaim for emphasizing Aaliyah’s vocal prowess, eventually earning the song a Grammy nomination. Stepping away from her accustomed smoother, ballad-like tunes and tones allowed Aaliyah all the more to display her exceptional feeling for rhythm and musical sensibility. Recognized for its use of a baby coo throughout the song, most notably sampled from Prince’s hit song “Delirious”, the production of “Are You That Somebody?” both complemented and challenged Aaliyah’s voice to create a sound mimicked well into the 21st century.

Two versions of the music video exist, the one with extracts from Dr. Dolittle being the most widespread (and the third most-played on MTV that year). But both feature the clip’s most recognizable characteristics: the futuristic entry into a cave (in L.A.’s Griffith Park), Playa on the background during Timbo’s rap, and Aaliyah’s range of dancing styles—including a short yet sweeping flamenco at the end.



As The Rolling Stone Album Guide notes, Timbaland’s innovative beats pushed Aaliyah rather than cradling her voice as R. Kelly’s did. With a blooming new personality infused into her music accompanied by entirely committed vocals, it is not difficult to see why the release of this hit “remains one of ‘90s’ R&B’s most astounding moments,” or how it inspired artists such as Beyoncé. Regardless of the successes of 21st-century R&B, however, “Are You That Somebody” forms a legacy of its own and continues to impress as modern musical creativity complimenting an unforgettable artist’s talents.

songs.full_title: At Your Best (You Are Love) by Aaliyah
songs.title: At Your Best (You Are Love)

description.plain:
“At Your Best (You Are Love)” is a track off of Aaliyah’s debut album, “Age Ain’t Nothing But a Number”. The song is a cover of “(At Your Best) You Are Love” by the American musical group, The Isley Brothers, released in 1976.

In a 1994 interview, when asked what is her favorite song from the album, Aaliyah responded saying,

My favorite song is At Your Best (You Are Love)… well because I love The Isley Brothers for one and all though I think the song is very special – the words and the lyrics are really heavy. The Isley’s – most of their songs, the lyrics are really something. You know you have to really listen and their songs are really deep and I thought that song was really special. When I first heard it, I fell in love with it –  when Robert brought it to my attention and I loved it ever since."

At Your Best (You Are Love) Lyrics[Intro]
Let me know, let me know
Oh, let me know

Let me, yeah

When you feel what you feel

I'm all about, all about

You're a positive, motivating force within my life
Should you ever feel the need to wonder why?
Let me know, let me know
Let me know, let me know

[Bridge]
Tell me what it is (Tell me what it is)
There's no need to make believe
Make believe, no need to make believe
Look beyond your own (Look beyond your own)
Try to find a place for me (Try and find, find a place for me)
'Cause

[Chorus]
At your best, you are love
You're a positive, motivating force within my life
Should you ever feel the need to wonder why?
Let me know, let me know
[Outro]

songs.full_title: Miss You by Aaliyah
songs.title: Miss You

description.plain:
“Miss You” is a song by American recording artist Aaliyah. Written by Johnta Austin, Ginuwine and Teddy Bishop in 1998 and initially recorded in the fall of 1999 for her self-titled third studio album (2001), the track remained unreleased. Instead, it was later included on the posthumously released compilation album, I Care 4 U (2002), serving as its leading single during the last quarter of 2002.

The ballad received positive reviews from contemporary music critics and achieved a strong charting throughout Europe and other worldwide regions, reaching the top twenty in Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, and Switzerland. On the US Billboard charts, the song peaked on top of the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart and reached number three on the Hot 100, becoming Aaliyah’s highest-charting single after her 2000 number-one hit “Try Again” featuring Timbaland.

The music video for the song was directed by Darren Grant and featured tributes by Aaliyah’s friends and collaborators, including DMX, Missy Elliott, and Static Major. It received a nomination for Best R&B Video at the 2003 MTV Video Music Awards. Rapper Jay-Z made a tribute to Aaliyah using the “Miss You” instrumental and chorus for its official remix version in Summer 2003.

songs.full_title: One In A Million by Aaliyah
songs.title: One In A Million

description.plain:
The title track in Aaliyah’s second studio album, “One in a Million” was considered an atypical R&B song at the time due to its almost drum-n-bass style beats. It was one of the early examples of Timbaland’s drum-skitter-style of programming.

In a 2015 interview with Billboard, Missy Elliott recalled the song’s release saying, “When we did [Aaliyah’s] ‘One in a Million,’ they wouldn’t play it at first because they said it was off—the rhythm, the melody, everything.” The song reached #1 on the R&B charts for 6 weeks.

songs.full_title: Age Ain't Nothing But a Number by Aaliyah
songs.title: Age Ain’t Nothing But a Number
songs.title_with_featured: Age Ain't Nothing But a Number

description.plain:
Written by R. Kelly, “Age ain’t nothing but a number” is a ballad from a young girl to an older boy (or man) about how age difference doesn’t matter in matters of the heart.

The title of this song and the album itself are scandalous in that it was rumored that Aaliyah was romantically involved with her producer R. Kelly.  At the time she was 15 (the song recorded when she was 14), and he was 27. It was also rumored that they married under false pretenses – A marriage certificate was printed in Vibe magazine stating that she was 18.

The most convincing version of what happened is told by Kelly’s ex-friend Demetrius Smith, he asserts it was a pregnancy scare:

he was given the advice that he could protect himself from the legal ramifications of the situation by marrying her. Smith’s account of what happened next: During a break in the tour, Smith and Kelly flew together to Illinois; Smith procured a fake state ID for Aaliyah from a friend in the Public Aid office, and they got a backup ID through someone they knew at Federal Express. That night, after the ceremony in a suite at a Sheraton hotel, Kelly and Smith flew back to Miami to resume the tour.



Since this song was made R. Kelly has had numerous sexual abuse allegations made against him, putting the song in an even more negative light than what it was originally released.

songs.full_title: Try Again by Aaliyah
songs.title: Try Again

description.plain:
The lead single of the soundtrack to the 2000 action film Romeo Must Die, later released as the 15th track of Aaliyah’s 2001 self-titled album. Written by Timbaland and Static Major, “Try Again” is about a woman who tries to encourage a guy she’s dating to “try again” in asking her out if it didn’t work out the first time, and not give up on the relationship before it gets a chance to start.

“Try Again” is one of Aaliyah’s biggest hits, becoming the first track to top the US Billboard Hot 100 chart on the strength of its radio airplay alone and receiving a Grammy nomination for Best Female R&B Vocal Performance at the 43rd Grammy Awards.

songs.full_title: More Than a Woman by Aaliyah
songs.title: More Than a Woman

description.plain:
More Than a Woman is the second single off of Aaliyahs' self-titled album. The dance-pop track was written by Static Major and contains a sample of the 1993 song “Alouli Ansa” by Syrian artist Mayada El Hennaway.

The song details Aaliyahs' attraction to a man and her desire to be a better lover than anybody he has ever been with.

Originally titled “draw the line”, early demos recorded by Static Major outline the love between Aaliyah and a man who may be cheating but also gives her a relationship so intimate that she has to question “where to draw the line”.

Released as a posthumous single in September of 2001, “more than a woman” received commercial success in the US and Europe peaking at 25 on the Billboard hot 100, 13 on the Irish charts, and number one in the UK in January of 2002, spending 25 weeks on the charts.

songs.full_title: Back & Forth by Aaliyah
songs.title: Back & Forth

description.plain:
“Back and Forth” was the debut single from late teen R&B sensation Aaliyah. The bass-heavy midtempo song featured unison female background vocals and rapped male chants that combined for a singalong-ready single. Its smooth and easy R&B sound became synonymous with summertime and 90’s party music.

The music video for the hit song established Aaliyah’s enduring street-but-sweet persona which paired her girl-next-door beauty with hard beats and hip-hop gear. Among the trademarks established were over-sized baggy pants, exposed boxer shorts, midriff-exposing half-shirts, sunglasses, and stark black straight-pressed hair under a bandana. This style would be associated with the singer throughout her career.

The song was written, produced by, and featured R&B singer R. Kelly who was still riding the wave of his wildly successful and sexually overt 1993 album 12 Play. “Back & Forth” was released May 10, 1994 and would eventually knock Kelly’s own “Your Body’s Callin'” out of the #1 spot.

Before the year’s end, Aaliyah (then aged 15) and Kelly (age 27) would be embroiled in a controversy surrounding an alleged underage marriage. The controversy lent a strangely charged feel to her mature-leaning debut album auspiciously titled Age Ain’t Nothing But A Number. The marriage was reportedly annulled in February of the following year.

songs.full_title: I Care 4 U by Aaliyah
songs.title: I Care 4 U

description.plain:
“I Care 4 U” is a song by Aaliyah written by Missy Elliott and Timbaland.

It was released as a radio single in 2003 in promotion of Aaliyah’s posthumuous compilation album I Care 4 U (2002).

Aaliyah has said in an interview:

“If I had to pick my favourite song from the album it would be I Care 4 U! I really wanted to put in on One In A Million but it was already mastered and there was no way I could get it on so we put it aside and waited…”

songs.full_title: Come Over by Aaliyah (Ft. Tank)
songs.title: Come Over

description.plain:
In this song from Aaliyah’s posthumous hits album I Care 4 U, Aaliyah gets off of a late night flight and can’t wait until morning to see her man.  She calls him and asks if she can come over to see him.

In 2003 “Come Over” peaked at number 32 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and number 9 on the R&B/Hip-Hop chart.



This song was recorded as a demo, and was later done by Changing Faces and released on their 2000 album Visit Me.

http://youtu.be/iV2Fw_NZQLI

description.plain: This song was leaked almost exactly 3 years after previewing it in an Instagram post. It was supposed to be on a posthumous collaboration album with Aaliyah, one of Drake’s biggest influences. However, Drake and 40, his longtime go-to producer, called the album off when Timbaland and Missy Elliot didn’t show their support, after which they released one of the 16 songs that were supposed to be on the album, Enough Said.

songs.full_title: We Need a Resolution by Aaliyah (Ft. Timbaland)
songs.title: We Need a Resolution

description.plain:
“We Need a Resolution” is a song performed by Aaliyah. It was written by Static Major and Timbaland, who also produced and contributed with a featured rap verse.

The song was released on April 13, 2001, as the lead single for Aaliyah’s self-titled 2001 album Aaliyah.

“We Need a Resolution” has a sparse arrangement with stop-start drum patterns, hand claps, and a clarinet sample from John Ottman’s “Tricks of the Trade” from the score to the 1997 film Incognito.

The song’s lyrics present two perspectives in a passive-aggressive relationship. Aaliyah’s sinuously sung concerns are playfully dismissed in Timbaland’s verse. The hook is left unresolved and plays backwards after Timbaland’s rap, concluding with a reversed loop of the vocal “where were you last night?”, echoing the female protagonist’s sentiment.

songs.full_title: If Your Girl Only Knew by Aaliyah
songs.title: If Your Girl Only Knew

description.plain:
The lead single from Aaliyah’s 2nd studio album One In a Million, “If your girl only knew” was released in 1996 and became Aaliyah’s 3rd single to reach top 20 on Billboard’s Hot 100.

Notably, “If Your Girl Only Knew” was one of the earliest songs that showcased the production talent of Timbaland.

–  Wiki

It was also the first song that really showcased Missy Elliott’s songwriting skills. While being responsible for writing the lyrics, Missy also provided the background vocals while Timbaland did the ad-libs throughout the track.

songs.full_title: Miss You (Remix) by Aaliyah (Ft. JAY-Z)
songs.title: Miss You (Remix)

description.plain:
This is Jay-Z’s official remix of Aaliyah’s track “Miss You,” which was officially released on April 29, 2003. Aaliyah recorded the original in 1999, and it was released posthumously in November 2002. Hov recorded his verses at the top of 2003.

The singer, who was a close friend of Hov, had tragically passed away after a plane crash in the Bahamas on August 25, 2001. Here he takes the chance to reminisce on their relationship while paying  tribute to her and the other fallen “soldiers and soldiettes” in the music game.

A portion of the single’s enhanced-CD sales was donated to the Aaliyah Memorial Fund.

songs.full_title: Poison by Aaliyah (Ft. The Weeknd)
songs.title: Poison

description.plain:
On “Poison,” Aaliyah and The Weeknd join forces to tell the story of a deteriorating, toxic, and loveless relationship, as they lament the realization of what their relationship has become and discuss their resulting feelings of heartbreak.

The track serves as the lead single to Unstoppable, Aaliyah’s fourth studio album and first posthumous album. The track’s existence was revealed on December 14, 2021, when it was included among a HitsDailyDouble list of tracks that were ready to be sent to radio stations of the Urban AC format. On the same day, the track premiered on Chicago’s 103.5 KISS FM radio station.

description.plain: Produced by Kay Gee & Darren Lighty, “A Girl Like You” is the forth song from Aaliyah’s second studio album; One in a Million. It samples Kool & the Gang’s song, “Summer Madness”. This was one of the first songs in hip-hop to feature a duet, where it’s not just a hip-hop artist putting a 16 on a R&B song or a R&B artist singing on a rap song, it fused the two together.

songs.full_title: Loose Rap by Aaliyah (Ft. Static Major)
songs.title: Loose Rap

description.plain:
“Loose Rap” is the 2nd track off of Aaliyah’s eponymous third album. It was originally intended to be the albums first single but “We Need A Resolution” replaced it in April 2001.

Although not a single, the song, which is about gossip and envy in relationships, quickly became one of the most popular tracks from the album.

songs.full_title: Never No More by Aaliyah
songs.title: Never No More

description.plain:
On this fifth track to Aaliyah’s self-titled album, she touches on a relationship that is seemingly coming to and end. In the beginning, she believes she can have a future with this man, until he continues to grow more hostile and abusive (physically and mentally).

Although she sees his consistent change in behavior, but considering she’s been blinded by love, Aaliyah holds onto the speck of hope that there is still good in him. However, she realizes that the way he is treating her is “way out of line” and that she should’ve left him at all of the previous red flags.

songs.full_title: Journey to the Past by Aaliyah
songs.title: Journey to the Past

description.plain:
“Journey To The Past” is a lighthearted inspirational pop song from the soundtrack of the 1997 animated film Anastasia. Though the song was performed by Liz Callaway for the film, R&B artist Aaliyah recorded the song for a commercial single release.

“Journey To The Past” was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Original Song. When a 19-year-old Aaliyah performed it at the Oscars in 1998, she became the youngest person ever to perform at the Oscars.

A music video shows Aaliyah performing while animation takes over her real-life scene. Later on, real-life Aaliyah is inserted into animated scenes from the movie.

songs.full_title: Got to Give It Up by Aaliyah (Ft. Slick Rick)
songs.title: Got to Give It Up
songs.title_with_featured: Got to Give It Up (Ft. Slick Rick)

description.plain:
Aaliyah explained how the remake came about:

“I wanted some real party songs, so when my uncle played me that [original track], I thought of how I could make it different. Slick Rick [who’d been in jail] was on work release at the time, so Vincent got him on the song.

“I don’t know how Marvin Gaye fans will react, but I hope they like it,” she continued. “I always think it’s a great compliment when people remake songs. I hope one day after I’m not here that people will cover my songs.”

Rest In Peace Baby Girl and Marvin Gaye.

songs.full_title: Down with the Clique by Aaliyah
songs.title: Down with the Clique

description.plain:
Aaliyah and R. Kelly address those who are part of or who admire their clique. In the song’s context,“down” means in favor of, playing off the contemporary phrase, “You down (to play ball, go to the movies, etc.)?” The song was originally titled “Who’s In Her Clique?” before being changed to “Down with the Clique” taken from the lyrics “If you down with the clique let me hear you say..I’m down with it”.

Due to the controversy surrounding Aaliyah & R. Kelly’s relationship at the time, no further singles were released from Age Ain’t Nothing But A Number In the United States.

This is another good song on the album that should have been a hit.

songs.full_title: I Can Be by Aaliyah
songs.title: I Can Be

description.plain:
“I Can Be” is the twelfth track taken from Aaliyah’s third and self-titled album, Aaliyah.

In 2001, VH1 asked Aaliyah what the track meant for her, she responded saying,

I like that song, because it speaks about being the other woman. There are relationships out there where a guy already has a girlfriend and he’s got one on the side, too. What’s cool about it is that music is for everyone to interpret in their own way. You may hear a song and feel one way about it, and I feel another. My interpretation of that song is, even though I’m singing about being the other woman in your life, I’ll be on the side, I don’t mind. It’s so dark. There’s a part of the character that is so depressing, it makes you feel she doesn’t really mean what she’s saying. She likes this guy, but she really doesn’t want to be the other girl on the side. It’s really a sad story, and I liked that. These songs on this album talk about relationships in every aspect."

songs.full_title: Hot Like Fire by Aaliyah
songs.title: Hot Like Fire

description.plain: “Hot Like Fire” was the album’s fourth and final single, and was a big hit all over the world. The song talks about a relationship that makes her burn up. Aaliyah sings that she wants her significant other to wait “a little while longer” before getting intimate, but when she is ready she will “take him higher. Aaliyah performs most of the song, while Timbaland contributes ad libs and Missy Elliott chants "I'ma make it hot like fire” as the intro.

songs.full_title: No One Knows How to Love Me Quite Like You Do by Aaliyah
songs.title: No One Knows How to Love Me Quite Like You Do
songs.title_with_featured: No One Knows How to Love Me Quite Like You Do

description.plain:
“No One Knows How to Love Me Quite Like You Do” is a R&B/hip-hop song performed by Aaliyah and Tia Hawkins. It was released as a promotional airplay single in the U.S. and is the fourth release from Aaliyah’s debut album Age Ain’t Nothing but a Number.

The single was written and produced by R. Kelly. On the song Aaliyah tells her lover, no one else knows how to love her quite like her guy does over a hip hop-styled beat.

description.plain:
The “Timbaland Remix” of “Hot Like Fire”  (also known as “Timbaland’s Groove Mix”) features on the maxi single for “The One I Gave My Heart To & Hot Like Fire” and on the “Hot Like Fire” 12" vinyl.

The main difference between this remix and the other one on the single is that there is a repetition of Aaliyah on this remix saying “oh no no no, oh no” throughout the instrumental.

songs.full_title: Never Givin' Up by Aaliyah (Ft. Tavarius Polk)
songs.title: Never Givin’ Up

description.plain:
“Never Givin' Up” is the 12th track on Aaliyah’s album One in a Million. It features a young thirteen year old at the time Tavarius Polk and is produced by Craig King & Vincent Herbert.

https://pbs.twimg.com/media/BAxETEfCIAAJICR?format=jpg&name=4096x4096

This is one of Aaliyah’s most slept on songs that she has ever recorded, the beat is so damn smooth and hard. You can’t listen to this song without getting into it! The song is about Aaliyah never giving up on the love she has for her significant other. Now we all got someone who we will never stop loving no matter what all you we’ve been through!

songs.full_title: I Refuse by Aaliyah
songs.title: I Refuse

description.plain:
“I Refuse” is a track from Aaliyah’s third and final album Aaliyah. The ominous midtempo song about ending an emotionally abusive relationship is awash in dramatic strings and electric guitar riffs. This song may have indicated a more rock-centered sound Aaliyah wanted to dabble in. An article from Complex Magazine reveals that almost happened:

Aaliyah was once asked on an episode of MTV Stipped if she liked rock music, to which she replied, “[I] like rock and all kinds of music.” Specifically, the singer happened to be a big fan of Nine Inch Nails. In 1999 she reached out to Trent Reznor to produce a song on her last album. The two camps engaged in discussions before her death but, ultimately, scheduling conflicts prevented the collaboration from happening.

songs.full_title: Messed Up by Aaliyah
songs.title: Messed Up

description.plain:
“Messed Up” is a hidden track that was included in the U.S version of Aaliyah’s self-titled third album, Aaliyah, released on July 17, 2001. The track was later included in posthumous compilation albums, Ultimate Aaliyah and Special Edition: Rare Tracks & Visuals.

What are hidden tracks? According to MusicianWave,

Hidden tracks often served as a fun ‘easter egg’ for a band’s most dedicated fans. Fans would often feel that they have exclusive access to songs that most casual listeners would not hear."

songs.full_title: I'm Down by Aaliyah
songs.title: I’m Down

description.plain: The final track off of Aaliyah’s 1994 debut album Age Ain’t Nothing But A Number revolves around her accepting the fact that she must be willing to sacrifice to be with her man. Being that R. Kelly was heavily involved in the writing and production of this song, along with the rest of the album, it was most likely made for Aaliyah to conform to be with him. Nonetheless, her riveting vocals on this track make it as smooth as the girl herself, and helped launch her into the superstar she was.

description.plain: The hook on this song is so smooth and I like it! Timbaland’s production is good man. This song did not receive that much recondition due to the others hits but in my eyes I like this one. The Donna Summers sample was smooth as well, the song also features Missy Elliot who was mighty close with Aaliyah.

songs.full_title: Are You Ready? by Aaliyah
songs.title: Are You Ready?

description.plain:
“Are You Ready?” is a R&B song performed by singer Aaliyah. The song was written by Renne A. Neuville & produced by DJ Kay Gee of Naughty by Nature for the soundtrack to the basketball film Sunset Park (1996). It was released as a promotional radio single for the soundtrack.

This song samples ‘Movin’ In The Right Direction' as performed by Steve Parks.

“Are You Ready?” received moderate airplay on some major market urban contemporary radio stations causing it to peak at #42 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay Chart. It was not eligible for the Billboard charts due to the song never being commercially released as a single.

songs.full_title: No Days Go By by Aaliyah
songs.title: No Days Go By

description.plain:
“No Days Go By” is a b-side to Aaliyah’s cover of Marvin Gaye’s “Got To Give It Up”. It was featured on the Australian and European singles. It was also featured on her album “One In A Million” in Japan. The song is about a guy that Aaliyah can not stop thinking about.

The song’s original unreleased version sampled vocals from Slick Rick’s interpolation of “Sukiyaki” by A Taste Of Honey from his song “La Di Da Di”. The sample was removed from the final version.

Here is the un-finalized version with Slick Rick’s sampled vocals. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RHDRNcGPHX0

Here is the final version
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qPE1oToCJ4w

songs.title: I Gotcha’ Back

description.plain: “I Gotcha Back” is a track from Aaliyah’s 1996 breakthrough album One In A Million. Produced by Jermaine Dupri and Carl So-Lowe, “I Gotcha Back” reprises the same sample of “I Want'a Do Something Freaky To You” by late soul singer Leon Haywood that was the basis of Dr. Dre & Snoop Dogg’s “Nuthin' But A ‘G’ Thang.” In the 90’s, it became very common for an sample driven hip-hop song to become a hit, and then have several R&B songs allude to the hip-hop song by using the same sample.

songs.full_title: The Thing I Like by Aaliyah
songs.title: The Thing I Like

description.plain:
The Thing I Like" is a song recorded in 1993 by American singer Aaliyah. It was released on the soundtrack for the action-comedy film A Low Down Dirty Shame(1994) and the international version of Aaliyah’s debut studio album Age Ain’t Nothing but a Number (1994).

 It was released as the album’s fifth single in Europe in 1995. Written and produced by R. Kelly, the song features a rap verse from himself. Its lyrics are about a girl’s love for a man because of the one “thing she likes” about him.

songs.full_title: Death of a Playa by Aaliyah (Ft. Rashad Haughton)
songs.title: Death of a Playa
songs.title_with_featured: Death of a Playa (Ft. Rashad Haughton)

description.plain:
“Death Of a Playa” by Aaliyah and her older brother, Rashad Haughton, was featured as the B-side of the single “4 Page Letter” and also featured on the CD single release of “One I Gave My Heart To/Hot Like Fire”“.

Released on March 11, 1997 through Blackground and Atlantic Records, this track centers around Aaliyah’s ability to make a man that was once promiscuous, into a faithful man with her.

songs.full_title: Where Could He Be? by Aaliyah (Ft. Missy Elliott & Tweet)
songs.title: Where Could He Be?
songs.title_with_featured: Where Could He Be? (Ft. Missy Elliott & Tweet)

description.plain:
Excerpt from Aaliyah Archives:

“The song was originally meant to be included on Aaliyah’s final studio album, but never made it to the cut. During 2005, the song got a lot of air play on the radio, and was expected to serve as a single for her second posthumous album titled The Aaliyah Duets Album. However, Blackground was not having any of this and stated that the track was illegally leaked, thus resulting all radio stations to remove the song”

http://www.aaliyaharchives.com/2013/09/aaliyah-where-could-he-be-ft-missy.html

songs.full_title: At Your Best (You Are Love) (Stepper's Ball Remix) by Aaliyah
songs.title: At Your Best (You Are Love) (Stepper’s Ball Remix)
songs.title_with_featured: At Your Best (You Are Love) (Stepper's Ball Remix)

description.plain:
The Stepper’s Ball remix is a remix of the Gangstar Child Remix of Aaliyah’s cover of the Isley Brother’s song “(At Your Best) You Are Love”.

Like the Gangstar Child Remix, it contains melody and musical interpolations of “You, Me and He” by Mtume.

songs.full_title: Time by Aaliyah
songs.title: Time

description.plain:
Aaliyah sadly didn’t have enough time to complete the whole of this song due to her passing away which is why the audio and lyrics are on a loop.

Rest in peace baby girl.

501 jeans with the black and gold reez-ag

songs.full_title: Giving Up by Aaliyah
songs.title: Giving Up

description.plain:
Aaliyah recorded this Donny Hathaway cover for the movie re-make of Sparkle which she was set to star in as one of the main roles chosen by Whitney Houston who was producing the re-make.

Sadly, Aaliyah’s death occurred before she could begin the filming so the movie was shut down, a few years later it re-casted the role and went back into production but then the release of Dream Girls completely ended it until it was scheduled for remake in 2011 with Jordin Sparks.

Though the character “Sister” sings this song in the movie, Aaliyah had reportedly recorded it as a demo audition.

songs.full_title: He Keeps Me Shakin' by Aaliyah
songs.title: He Keeps Me Shakin’

description.plain:
“He Keeps Me Shakin'” was previously reworked on Aaliyah’s song called Quit Hatin’ which was leaked in early 2013.

“He Keeps Me Shakin’” was produced by duo Key Beats and is unfinished – according to its producers, Aaliyah sang only one verse (included on Quit Hatin’) and the hook that is yet unheard to the public.

(Source)

songs.full_title: Girlfriends (Without Rap) by Aaliyah
songs.title: Girlfriends (Without Rap)

description.plain:
“Girlfriends” is an unreleased track by Aaliyah.

The song talks about Aaliyah and her girlfriends, who have no trouble moving on from a man if he decides to act up because they have each other.

There are two known versions of this song:

The version with Aaliyah only who starts the song with the first verse (Main Version W/O Rap or Demo Version as Aaliyah does say “Yaushameen”).

It was uploaded by DJ Carisma on YouTube and SoundCloud (Source).

The other version features a lady named Yaushameen Michael and she starts the song off with the rap.

The song talks about Aaliyah and her girlfriends, who have no trouble moving on from a man if he decides to act up because they have each other.

There are two known versions of this song:

The version with Aaliyah only who starts the song with the first verse (Main Version W/O Rap or Demo Version as Aaliyah does say “Yaushameen”).

It was uploaded by DJ Carisma on YouTube and SoundCloud (Source).

The other version features a lady named Yaushameen Michael and she starts the song off with the rap.
